title: feat(vis_type_vega): support reading time field
body:
### Description

This PR introduces time range filter support to Vega visualizations with PPL queries. When `"%timefield%"` is specified, the time range filter from the dashboard will be applied to the PPL query automatically.

#### Before This PR
Vega visualizations with PPL queries did not respect the time range set on the dashboard. Regardless of the selected time range, the query remained unaffected.

#### After This PR
With the addition of `"%timefield%"`, changing the time range filter on a dashboard now impacts Vega visualizations with PPL queries.

#### Example
```diff
{
    "$schema": "https://vega.github.io/schema/vega-lite/v5.json",
    "data": {
        "url": {
+            "%timefield%": "timestamp",
            "%type%": "ppl",
            "body": {
                "query": "source=opensearch_dashboards_sample_data_logs | stats count() as request_count by extension | sort -request_count"
            }
        }
    }
}
```

title: Create cypress command namespacing util
body:
### Description

This is to enable namespaced Cypress commands. This allows us to prevent unintentional Cypress command name collisions with 3rd party Commands. I've also gone ahead and migrated 2 utils which serve as examples and verifications.

Once we've merged, we can use this to create new cypress utils and decide on what priority (if any) we want for migrating old utils.

Example usage
```js
// commands.js
initCommandNamespace(cy, 'osd');

cy.osd.add('getBody', () => cy.get('body')); // add command to namespace

// myTest.spec.js
it('should render body', () => {
    cy.osd.getBody().should('exist');
});
```

## Testing the changes
With the two migrated utils, tests should all pass. If the s3 dataset tests fail it's a good indication that there's an issue with this PR that needs to be resolved before merging.

## Changelog

title: [BUG] Extreme slow Login compared to Playground

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

body:
**Describe the bug**

The Login to Opensearch Dashboards is really slow compared to the playground.
The Setup has an AD connected but I used a local User with `kibana_read_only` set, to test

Till the call to `/api/ism/accountInfo` the Time is comparable to the playground.
But the call to `/api/ism/accountInfo` took 2,31 seconds 
`/api/core/capabilities` seem to be the worst with 7,36 seconds
URL | Duration | Duration Playground
-- | -- | --
/api/ism/accountInfo | 2,31 | 0,264
/api/v1/restapiinfo | 1,02 | 0,23
/api/v1/configuration/account | 1,19 | 0,152
/api/v1/auth/dashboardsinfo | 1,21 | 0,177
/api/core/capabilities | 7,36 | 0,187

I'm running a 3 node Opensearch Cluster with Dashboards installed on each node.
The Nodes have 32GB Memory and 24GB of it are assigned to Opensearch.
So Opensearch Dashboards and the OS should have 8GB to use.

I already tried to disable unneeded Plugins, but it seems to not have any great improvements.
How can I debug if the Opensearch-Dashboards is the culprit or Opensearch itself?

A simple empty search with the same User direct on Opensearch seems fast:
```
curl -o /dev/null -s -w 'Total: %{time_total}s\n' 'https://:9200/_search' -X POST -u user:pw --data-raw '{"size":0}'
Total: 0.199682s

```
**Expected behavior**
Fast login like the Playground

**OpenSearch Version**
v 2.18.0

**Dashboards Version**
v 2.18.0

**Plugins**
indexManagementDashboards@2.18.0.0
queryWorkbenchDashboards@2.18.0.0
reportsDashboards@2.18.0.0
securityAnalyticsDashboards@2.18.0.0
securityDashboards@2.18.0.0


**Screenshots**
The last column is the duration of the Request, the one before is when the Request started.
My Setup
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/22fb0c24-8232-4ede-9673-0bb637d7b5ed)
The Playground:
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/44823f5a-c006-4e2a-9b60-2652513c787c)

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

body: **Describe the bug** Currently, on your maps, Crimea is depicted as part of the Russian Federation. However, under international law, Crimea is recognized as part of Ukraine. The United Nations General Assembly passed a resolution (A/RES/68/262) in 2014, affirming Ukraine's territorial integrity and recognizing Crimea as part of Ukraine, following its illegal annexation by the Russian Federation. I respectfully request that you contact your map provider in order to update the maps to reflect the internationally recognized status of Crimea as part of Ukraine, in accordance with international law. This change would ensure the accuracy and neutrality of the OpenSearch platform. I am going to register a corresponding request on OpenStreetMap, as the society responsible for the map, but meanwhile, I would appreciate your attention to this matter to resolve this law violation in the shortest terms possible. **To Reproduce** Steps to reproduce the behavior: 1. Deploy the latest version of the OpenSearch Dashboards 2. Create a Map visualization 3. Use a standard Vector map "World countries" 4. Navigate to the Crimia 5. See error **Expected behavior** Map to be in accordance to the international law. **Dashboards Version** opensearchproject/opensearch-dashboards:2.18.0 **Screenshots**

title: [Workspace] Add APIs for getting workspace users and roles
body:
### Description

Add APIs for getting workspace users and roles and `opensearchDashboards.identity.source` feature flag.

The `opensearchDashboards.identity.source` feature flag enables dynamic identity management by allowing the registration of customized getUsers and getRoles APIs for different identity sources. By specifying a source (e.g., local_cluster), the system intelligently routes API calls to the appropriate implementation, ensuring that identity operations are seamlessly adapted to the selected source. This flexibility simplifies the integration of diverse identity providers, streamlining user and role management across varying environments.
By default, users and roles are retrieved through the identity source registered within the `security-dashboard-plugin`. This ensures a seamless integration with the default identity management system, providing a consistent and secure mechanism for handling user and role data.

### Issues Resolved
N/A

## Screenshot

Only backend changes

## Testing the changes
Assuming that the identity source has already been registered in the security plugins.

Get all users
```zsh
curl -X POST -H "osd-xsrf: string" -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
-d '{}' \
"http://localhost:5601/api/workspaces/identity/_users" -u 'admin:myStrongPassword123!' --insecure

[
    {
        "name": "logstash",
        "id": "logstash"
    },
    {
        "name": "test",
        "id": "test"
    },
    {
        "name": "snapshotrestore",
        "id": "snapshotrestore"
    },
    {
        "name": "admin",
        "id": "admin"
    },
    {
        "name": "kibanaserver",
        "id": "kibanaserver"
    },
    {
        "name": "kibanaro",
        "id": "kibanaro"
    },
    {
        "name": "readall",
        "id": "readall"
    },
    {
        "name": "anomalyadmin",
        "id": "anomalyadmin"
    }
]
```

Get all roles
```zsh
curl -X POST -H "osd-xsrf: string" -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
-d '{}' \
"http://localhost:5601/api/workspaces/identity/_roles" -u 'admin:myStrongPassword123!' --insecure

[
    {
        "name": "logstash",
        "id": "logstash"
    },
    {
        "name": "snapshotrestore",
        "id": "snapshotrestore"
    },
    {
        "name": "admin",
        "id": "admin"
    },
    {
        "name": "kibanauser",
        "id": "kibanauser"
    },
    {
        "name": "readall",
        "id": "readall"
    }
]
```

title: [Auto Suggest] Fix Grammar Changes
body:
### Description

Based on https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch-Dashboards/pull/8275. Diff while that PR is still unmerged: https://github.com/paulstn/OpenSearch-Dashboards/compare/autosuggest-value-suggestion...paulstn:OpenSearch-Dashboards:autosuggest-redo-grammar-changes

Redos changes made to the grammar meant for fixing bugs. Fixes those same original bugs through other means.

Also rewrites the 'redo and combine' functionality to be more robust.
<Explain prev. system and new system>
The old system was simply a flag that could be set by a preferred rule to run code completion once with all the rules, and then another time without any rules, to finally combine the results from both.
The new system requires any preferred rule to submit its name, and then goes through that cumulative list to remove only that rule from the code completion process, combining every possible result it gets. This new system allows for multiple preferred rules to be left out of the code completion process if it happens to block keyword candidates, and also for every other potentially necessary preferred rule to still be in effect while it does so.


----
Removes grammar changes from:
https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch-Dashboards/pull/8087/files#diff-3dc92487ddb63ebd741b8639f39b9440158a1f31317978cbd84af144daf3adc0



### Issues Resolved

<!-- List any issues this PR will resolve. Prefix the issue with the keyword closes, fixes, fix -->
<!-- Example: closes #1234 or fixes <Issue_URL> -->


- [search source with logical expressions](https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch-Dashboards/pull/8087/files#diff-3dc92487ddb63ebd741b8639f39b9440158a1f31317978cbd84af144daf3adc0L56-R57), reverting required a preferred rule on logical expression to prevent code completion issues and a new redo and combine function

title: [BUG] Opensearch Dashboards. Otel + Jaeger vs DataPrepper. No errors statistics from DataPrepper perspective for review.

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

body: **Setup**: Otel Agents -> Otel collector -> Jaeger / DataPrepper -> Opensearch -> OpensearchDashboards **Versions**: Opensearch Helm Chart version: 2.27.1, appVersion: 2.18.0 Opensearch-Dashboards Helm Chart version: 2.25.0, appVersion: 2.18.0 Jaeger Helm Chart version: 3.3.3, appVersion: 1.53.0 DataPrepper Helm Chart version: 0.1.0, appVersion: 2.8.0 **Describe the issue**: I have a setup with instrumented applications using OpenTelemetry (Otel) agents, which push traces to an Otel collector. The Otel collector sends data to both Jaeger and DataPrepper. However, I am noticing a difference in the behavior of the same traces when viewed in OpenSearch Dashboards depending on the data source selected (Jaeger vs. DataPrepper). Specifically, when I select DataPrepper as the data source, I do not see the entire trace being marked as a trace with errors, and the errors are not displayed on the dashboard. In contrast, when using Jaeger as the data source, the errors are correctly visualized, and the entire trace is marked as an "error trace" if any span within the trace contains an error. **Configuration**: Jaeger: ``` jaeger: agent: enabled: false provisionDataStore: cassandra: false elasticsearch: false collector: enabled: true annotations: {} image: registry: "" repository: jaegertracing/jaeger-collector tag: "" digest: "" envFrom: [] cmdlineParams: {} basePath: / replicaCount: 1 service: otlp: grpc: name: "otlp-grpc" port: 4317 http: name: "otlp-http" port: 4318 serviceAccount: create: true storage: type: elasticsearch elasticsearch: scheme: http host: opensearch-cluster-master.opensearch-otel.svc.cluster.local port: 9200 anonymous: true usePassword: false - name: SPAN_STORAGE_TYPE value: "opensearch" - name: ES_TAGS_AS_FIELDS_ALL value: "true" tls: enabled: false ``` DataPrepper: ``` config: otel-trace-pipeline: delay: "1000" source: otel_trace_source: ssl: false buffer: bounded_blocking: buffer_size: 10240 batch_size: 160 sink: - pipeline: name: "raw-traces-pipeline" - pipeline: name: "otel-service-map-pipeline" raw-traces-pipeline: source: pipeline: name: "otel-trace-pipeline" buffer: bounded_blocking: buffer_size: 10240 batch_size: 160 processor: - otel_trace_raw: - otel_trace_group: hosts: [ "http://opensearch-cluster-master:9200" ] insecure: true sink: - opensearch: hosts: [ "http://opensearch-cluster-master:9200" ] insecure: true index_type: trace-analytics-raw otel-service-map-pipeline: delay: "1000" source: pipeline: name: "otel-trace-pipeline" buffer: bounded_blocking: buffer_size: 10240 batch_size: 160 processor: - service_map_stateful: window_duration: 300 sink: - opensearch: hosts: [ "http://opensearch-cluster-master:9200" ] insecure: true index_type: trace-analytics-service-map index: otel-v1-apm-span-%{yyyy.MM.dd} #max_retries: 20 bulk_size: 4 ``` **Relevant Logs or Screenshots**: DataPrepper source. Error in span, but not all trace marked with Error, and no statistics observed Here is Jaeger source. Error is observed in span and the whole trace marked with error (in the right top corner, next capture) Please share your suggestions on how to fix it. TraceID is the same for both cases. Thanks

Documents from a CROSS JOIN between two indexes, depending on the order of the indexes in the query, sometimes contain fields from the other index but null, or sometimes they are completely missing.

When filtering the results for a specific manufacturer in either PPL or SQL-mode it seems like results not having that manufacturer is returned


**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Login anonymous in the future playground.
2. Select the **OTEL demo environment**.
3. Select **Discover** from the menu on the left hand side
4. In the data source selection dropdown, select `opensearch*ecomm*`
5. Using PPL query mode, set the time filter to absolute mode starting at `Oct 20, 2024 @ 00:00:00.00` and ending at `Oct 20, 2024 @23:00:00.00` then run `source = opensearch*ecomm* | where manufacturer = "Oceanavigations"`,
6. Notice how not every `manufacturer`-field has the value `Oceanavigations`, some have e.g. `Low Tide Media`.



**Expected behavior**
When using the specific filter one would expect result to have the manufacturer field set to `Oceanavigations`.
 
**OpenSearch Version**

2.18

**Dashboards Version**

2.18

**Plugins**

Alerting, anomaly-detection, asynchronous-search, cross-cluster-replication, custom-codecs, flow-framework, geospatial, index-management, job-scheduler, knn, ml, neural-search, notifications, notifications-core, observability, performance-analyzer, reports-scheduler, security, security-analytics, skills, sql, system-templates, query-insights

**Screenshots**

N/A

**Host/Environment:**

 - OS: macOS
 - Browser and version Google Chrome, version 131.0.6778.205

**Additional context**
Running the equivalent SQL-query `SELECT * from opensearch*ecomm* where manufacturer = "Oceanavigations"` shows a similar result where not every manufacturer-field is set to `Oceanavigations`.
However, running the DQL query `manufacturer: Oceanavigations`, it can be seen that several documents have multiple manufacturers e.g. `manufacturer: Oceanavigations, Low Tide Media`.
Peeking in the developer console it can be seen that the results are represented very differently if the query mode is DQL or PPL/SQL. It appears as if PPL/SQL-representations can only handle a single value, whereas DQL can handle an array.

title: refactor some query-enhancement utility functions, add some missing typings

labels.name: discover_2.0-test
labels.description: Issues that are specific to the Discover 2.0 testing initiative

body:
### Description

Refactors/additions for Cypress Query Enhancements

- update the custom command `waitForLoader` to take optional arg `isEnhancement: boolean`
- remove the `cy.wait()` within `waitForLoader` to speed up the command
- remove the now redundant `waitForLoaderNewHeader` command and refactor its' usage to be `waitForLoader(true)`
- add typescript typings to some of our custom commands
- refactor createWorkspaceIndexPatterns
    - conditionally call `cy.get('[type="data-source"]').contains(dataSource).click();` if `dataSource` prop is provided. This is because if your ws only has one data source, then this step is not visible in the UI, and this utility will fail
    - add optional arg `indexPatternHasTimefield: boolean`. This is needed because if the index pattern you select does not have a timefield, then the option of choosing a timestamp field does not appear, causing the test to fail
    - add the `isEnhancement: boolean` prop
 - add `deleteWorkspaceIndexPatterns` utility
 - refactor `navigateToWorkSpaceSpecificPage` to be less flaky
    - one thing to call out. I noticed a lot of flaky tests due to the nature of our left menu bar. The left menu bar's `open` state persists through navigation and refreshes. Therefore, in order to maintain consistent state before & after a function is run, if a function opens the bar, we should also add a step that closes it. This way we do not have to keep track of it's `open` state.

title: Fix add to dashboard after saving (with unit tests)
body:
### Description

When creating a new visualization from a dashboard, and saving it with the "Add to Dashboards after saving" toggle checked, adding the newly saved visualization to the dashboard can fail. This is easily reproducible when `storeInSessionStorage` is enabled.

The way it is supposed to work is that the `scopedHistory` receives the ID of the newly create visualization in the current location state, and the dashboard container uses that to add the visualization. However, when the dashboard application state is created, it can update the URL at startup, which causes the location state to be lost. This fix preserves the current `scopedHistory` location state across that URL update.

original PR: 
- #8164

### Issues Resolved

<!-- List any issues this PR will resolve. Prefix the issue with the keyword closes, fixes, fix -->
<!-- Example: closes #1234 or fixes <Issue_URL> -->

- Fix add to dashboard after saving
- #7204

  Please provide detailed steps for validating your changes. This could involve specific commands to run,
  pages to visit, scenarios to try or any other information that would help reviewers verify
  the functionality of your change
-->
1. Enable storeInSessionStorage
2. Go to an existing dashboard and click Edit
3. Click Create New
4. Pick a visualization, make whatever changes are desired, then click Save
5. Ensure "Add to Dashboards after saving" is enabled in the modal, then click Save and Return
6. The new visualization should be added to the dashboard. This would fail before this change.

title: Bundle refs optimization not applied when building plugins separately

labels.name: build
labels.description: Build related additions or modifications

body:
## Introduction
When building a plugin(run `yarn build` in a plugin folder), if the plugin statically imports module from OSD core or from OSD core plugins, currently, webpack will bundle the core modules as well with the current plugin bundle. The bundle optimization is not working at the moment.

Ideally, when a plugin import modules from core/core plugins, the core modules should not be bundled with the plugin but instead it should read the existing core modules from global variable `window.__osdBundles__` at runtime. Otherwise, it will make the plugin bundle size larger than it should be, also the plugin bundle will contain unnecessary chunks.

I did a few tweaks to the build scripts and `@osd/optimizer` package to make bundle refs optimization works for plugin builds. And I also did the following experiment tries to analyze the difference before the optimization(the current situation) and after the optimization(bundle refs optimization applied).

## The Experiment
The experiment was conducted in the way:
1. Deploy an official 2.18 release of docker image
2. Deploy a 2.18 docker image built by opensearch-build with applying the bundle refs optimization
3. Compare the size difference of js assets transferred through network when opening OSD
4. Compare the difference of js files in each plugin’s `public` folder

## Compressed JS assets transferred through network
The table shows the difference of javascript assets transferred through network after compression. We can see **significant reduction** in js assets size after applying the bundle refs optimization.

| Name                                   | Before   | After    | Diff (KB) | Diff (%)  |
|----------------------------------------|----------|----------|-----------|-----------|
| mlCommonsDashboards.plugin.js          | 136014   | 2823     | -133kb    | -97.9%    |
| notificationsDashboards.plugin.js      | 162913   | 7036     | -156kb    | -95.7%    |
| searchRelevanceDashboards.plugin.js    | 137825   | 7715     | -130kb    | -94.4%    |
| assistantDashboards.plugin.js          | 1012687  | 99067    | -914kb    | -90.2%    |
| queryWorkbenchDashboards.plugin.js     | 47587    | 5387     | -42kb     | -88.7%    |
| anomalyDetectionDashboards.plugin.js   | 1064138  | 132692   | -931kb    | -87.5%    |
| alertingDashboards.plugin.js           | 1338032  | 375764   | -962kb    | -71.9%    |
| customImportMapDashboards.plugin.js    | 1071663  | 332630   | -739kb    | -69.0%    |
| mlCommonsDashboards.chunk.2.js         | 35626    | 12619    | -23kb     | -64.6%    |
| reportsDashboards.plugin.js            | 472540   | 301062   | -171kb    | -36.3%    |
| indexManagementDashboards.plugin.js    | 472422   | 330714   | -142kb    | -30.0%    |
| observabilityDashboards.plugin.js      | 2589382  | 2009033  | -580kb    | -22.4%    |
| securityDashboards.plugin.js           | 602961   | 478757   | -124kb    | -20.6%    |
| securityAnalyticsDashboards.plugin.js  | 633582   | 513454   | -120kb    | -19.0%    |
| ganttChartDashboards.plugin.js         | 1481158  | 1381977  | -99kb     | -6.7%     |

The following tables show a few examples of the js files in each plugin’s target/public folder in OSD server, .gz and .br files are excluded.  Not all plugins are listed, but you get an idea of how the plugin bundles look like before and after bundle refs optimization.

It compares the original assets generated by webpack before and after the bundle refs optimization applied, we can see **huge difference in the number of generated chunks**, as well as significant difference in terms of the chunk size.

title: [BUG] Dashboard is very slow after upgrading to 2.17.0 (Response time increased alot)

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

body:
**Describe the bug**
After upgrading to opensearch 2.17.0 the UI became very slow, i.e the spinning ball keeps on rotating and loads the data very slow(this happens even on 15 mins time frame)
A clear and concise description of what the bug is.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Go to 'Discover'
2. Click on 'any index'
The response time is very slow 

**Expected behavior**
The Dashboard on 2.6.0 is very quick(Tested this with the second cluster which has same data and same resources), however the upgraded cluster dashboard is very slow, you can notice the spinnig wheel keeps on rotating.

**OpenSearch Version**
Please list the version of OpenSearch being used.
2.17.0
**Dashboards Version**
Please list the version of OpenSearch Dashboards being used.
2.17.0
**Plugins**
only using s3 plugin and security plugin apart from that no plugs are installed/newly added after ugprade
Please list all plugins currently enabled.
s3 plugin and security
**Screenshots**
![Screenshot 2024-12-17 at 12 52 36 PM](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/8e1dce3e-7039-411d-b49d-e283bb24035c)

If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem.

**Host/Environment (please complete the following information):**
These clusters are running on LKE with opensearch operator version 2.6.1 running on cluster which has 2.17.0 opensearch and opensearch operator 2.3.2 on the cluster which has 2.6.0 opensearch version.


 - OS: [e.g. iOS]
 - Browser and version [e.g. 22] Tried on Chrome, firefox, safari all the browsers its same.

**Additional context**
We are using the opensearch cluster on LKE Env the cluster is a big cluster with around 25 hot, 38 warm and 4 coordinator nodes(may be around 300-400 TB of data), jvm is given max allowed i.e 31 Gb on hot and warm nodes, for dasboard pods we gave 8 gb mem, 8 core cpu each and we have now have 3 dashboard pods, i don't see any pressure on mem or cpu in the pod usage still the UI is very slow when compared with other cluster which has 2.6.0 (both clusters have almost same resources) 
Add any other context about the problem here.
When we tried tailing dashboard logs on both the clusters i.e 2.17.0 and 2.6.0 i see a huge increase in response time in the dashboards 2.17.0 where as a similar cluster with opensearch 2.6.0 takes very little response time.

title: Discover Dashboard - Problem with Horizontal scrollbar visibility. Not able to scroll left/right until scroll down till the bottom.

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

I'm always frustrated when using Discover dashboard with large data set with multiple columns.
Horizontal Scrollbar is not visible until scroll down to the last record. Since the data is lazy loaded, it takes time to finish loading all the records. Until then I need to keep on scrolling.
Issue is present in both the Default and Legacy mode.

Attached below the video.

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/50823abd-88b1-4666-bd46-912fb5ca0aac

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Table should have always visible scrollbar like earlier version. I should be able to scroll left and right anytime view the hidden columns. 
Ex:

title: [BUG] Multitenancy: separate tenants cannot be used in different browser tabs

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

body:
**Describe the bug**
If I have two browser tabs open, and I select Tenant A in one tab, and then select Tenant B in the second tab, requests made in the first tab will get mapped to the tenant that was selected in the second tab. So, in the first tab, even though it says Tenant A is the current tenant, all saved objects that are pulled up will in fact be from Tenant B.

**To Reproduce**
- Configure Dashboards to have two or more tenants
- Change to one of those tenants (Tenant A)
- Open a new tab
- Select another tenant in the 2nd tab (Tenant B)
- Go back to the first tab and search for dashboards, visualizations, etc.

**Expected behavior**
The first tab should return results from Tenant A

**Actual behavior**
The first tab returns results from Tenant B, despite saying Tenant A is the current tenant

**OpenSearch Version**
2.18.0

**Dashboards Version**
2.18.0

**Plugins**
- Security

**Screenshots**

If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem.

**Host/Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Windows 11
 - Browser and version: Chrome 131

**Additional context**
I believe this is because the selected tenant is being saved in a cookie, which is being reused across browser tabs

title: [BUG] Search query is not saved when clicking on a link with saved search

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

body: **Describe the bug** The search query is not saved when you click on a link with saved search. It can be either a short link or a full link, with all the request parameters. It can be seen that in the request parameters contain ```code query:(language:lucene,query: test) ``` or ```code query:(language:kuery,query: test) ``` but when the page loads, the line disappears from the search. This is most likely due to the order in which the parameters are applied. The search parameter is applied first, and then it is overwritten by the saved search. **To Reproduce** Steps to reproduce the behavior: 1. Go to 'Discover' 2. Select index-pattern for search 3. Click "Save" and save search 4. Click "Open", select saved search 5. On the left upper corner you can see "Discover/${your_saved_search}" 6. Enter something in the search bar 7. Press "Share"->"Copy link" 8. Open the tab and follow the link 10. You will see that the search parameter has disappeared and it has disappeared from the query string 11. If in the same tab you follow the full link with search parameters, then everything works correctly **Expected behavior** It is expected that the link will open a search with the saved search parameter and search string **OpenSearch Version** 2.18.0 **Dashboards Version** 2.18.0 **Plugins** Only default plugins and Security **Screenshots** **Host/Environment (please complete the following information):** - OS: macos - Firefox/Chrome **Additional context** Full link of search ```code https://test-cluster.com/app/data-explorer/discover/#/view/17562920-b3e5-11ef-9242-cd847e376417?_q=(filters:!(),query:(language:kuery,query:Connection))&_g=(filters:!(),refreshInterval:(pause:!t,value:0),time:(from:now-15m,to:now))&_a=(discover:(columns:!(_source),isDirty:!f,savedSearch:'17562920-b3e5-11ef-9242-cd847e376417',sort:!()),metadata:(indexPattern:'security-auditlog-*',view:discover)) ``` Search link after follow ``` https://test-cluster.com/app/data-explorer/discover/#/view/17562920-b3e5-11ef-9242-cd847e376417?_q=(filters:!(),query:(language:kuery,query:''))&_g=(filters:!(),refreshInterval:(pause:!t,value:0),time:(from:now-15m,to:now))&_a=(discover:(columns:!(_source),isDirty:!f,savedSearch:'17562920-b3e5-11ef-9242-cd847e376417',sort:!()),metadata:(indexPattern:'security-auditlog-*',view:discover)) ``` Search query param erased

title: Horizontal Scroll Bar Not Rendered Until Last Record in search query result is Reached in OpenSearch Dashboards v2.18 which was working on for few records on OSD 1.3.17  version

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

body:
**What is the bug?**
In OpenSearch Dashboards version 2.18, the horizontal scroll bar in the table displaying search query results does not render  until the user scrolls to the last record in the table. This behavior was not observed in version 1.3.17, where the horizontal scroll bar was immediately accessible, allowing users to scroll horizontally regardless of their vertical position in the table.

This issue impacts usability, especially for tables with a significant number of columns, as users cannot view data that requires horizontal scrolling until they manually scroll down to the last record.

**How can one reproduce the bug?**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

Open OpenSearch Dashboards version 2.18.
Run a search query that returns results with multiple columns and rows.
Try to use the horizontal scroll bar without scrolling down to the last record.
Observe that the horizontal scroll bar is neither rendered nor operable until the last record is reached.

**What is the expected behavior?**
The horizontal scroll bar should be rendered and operable immediately, allowing horizontal navigation irrespective of the user's vertical position in the table.

Actual Behavior
The horizontal scroll bar is only rendered or becomes operable when the user scrolls to the last record in the table.

**What is your host/environment?**
OpenSearch Dashboards Version: 2.18

**Do you have any screenshots?**
attaching screenshot as per mentioned version for the same.
Opensearch-dashboards   1.13.7
 
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/749749fd-2304-4077-9fd0-54cc0218bf25)

Opensearch Dashboard 2.18.0

title: [Alignment] Align the description for visbuilder aggregation config parameters
body:
We aim to develop a feature that translates natural language into VisBuilder configurations. Specifically, when a user poses a question related to an index, we will leverage LLMs to generate the following based on the user's query and the index:

1. Filters
2. Chart type
3. Aggregation configuration parameters (AggConfigParams)

To ensure accuracy, we have compiled parameter descriptions for various aggregations based on the source code in this [directory](https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch-Dashboards/tree/539675e688061e689b362801bcb05a3ef78431b2/src/plugins/data/common/search/aggs), as summarized in the table below.

We want to confirm the correctness of these descriptions and align them with the code owners. Please review the information and provide comments if you identify any errors or missing details.

## Metric aggregation
### normal metric aggregation
| Agg | Field Name | Type | Description | Optional |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| median | field | string | The name of the field for which the median value will be calculated. The field must be of type 'number', 'date', or 'histogram'. | False |
| standard_deviation | field | string | The name of the field for which the standard deviation will be calculated. The field must be of type 'number'. | False |
| unique_count | field | string | The name of the field for which the unique count will be calculated. Supports all data types except histograms. | False |
| min | field | string | The name of the field for which the minimum value will be calculated. The field must be of type 'number' or 'date'. | False |
| max | field | string | The name of the field for which the maximum value will be calculated. The field must be of type 'number' or 'date'. | False |
| sum | field | string | The name of the field for which the sum will be calculated. The field must be of type 'number' or 'histogram'. | False |
| top_hit | field | string | The field from which the top hit(s) will be retrieved. Supports most data types except histograms. | False |
| top_hit | aggregate | string | Specifies the aggregation operation to perform on the top hits, such as 'min', 'max', 'sum', 'average', or 'concat'. | False |
| top_hit | size | number | The number of top hits to retrieve. | True |
| top_hit | sortField | string | The field to sort by when determining the top hit(s). Supports numeric, date, IP, and string fields. | True |
| top_hit | sortOrder | string | The sort order for the top hit(s). Can be 'desc' for descending or 'asc' for ascending. | True |
| avg | field | string | Specifies the numeric or histogram field on which the average aggregation will be performed. | False |
| percentile | field | string | The name of the field for which percentiles will be calculated. The field must be of type 'number', 'date', or 'histogram'. | False |
| percentile | percents | array of numbers | Defines the percentiles to compute. The default set includes common percentiles such as 1st, 5th, 25th, 50th, 75th, 95th, and 99th. | True |
| cardinality | field | string | The name of the field for which the unique count will be calculated. Supports all data types except histograms. | False |

### parent metric aggregation
| Agg | Field Name | Type | Description | Optional |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| moving_avg | buckets_path | string | Specifies the path to the buckets from which the moving average is calculated. It must reference a metric or aggregation result. | False |
| moving_avg | window | number | The size of the moving average window, specifying how many data points to include in the calculation. | True |
| moving_avg | script | string | A script that defines the calculation logic for the moving average. Defaults to an unweighted average. | True |
| moving_avg | customMetric | object | Defines a custom metric to be used for the moving average calculation. Allows overriding the default metric configuration. | True |
| moving_avg | metricAgg | string | The ID of the metric aggregation whose results are used in the moving average calculation. | True |
| cumulative_sum | buckets_path | string | Specifies the path to the buckets for which the cumulative sum is calculated. It must reference a metric or aggregation result. | False |
| cumulative_sum | customMetric | object | Specifies a custom metric to be used for the cumulative sum calculation. This can override the default metric configuration. | True |
| cumulative_sum | metricAgg | string | The ID of the metric aggregation to use as the input for the cumulative sum calculation. | True |
| serial_diff | buckets_path | string | Specifies the path to the buckets from which the serial difference is calculated. It must reference a metric or aggregation result. | False |
| serial_diff | customMetric | object | Defines a custom metric to be used for calculating the serial difference. This allows customization of the metric configuration. | True |
| serial_diff | metricAgg | string | The ID of the metric aggregation whose results are used for the serial difference calculation. | True |
| derivative | buckets_path | string | Specifies the path to the buckets from which the derivative is calculated. It must reference a metric or aggregation result. | False |
| derivative | customMetric | object | Defines a custom metric to be used for the derivative calculation. This allows overriding the default metric configuration. It should be a normal metric aggregation | False |
| derivative | metricAgg | string | The ID of the metric aggregation whose results are used in the derivative calculation. | False |

### sibling metric aggregation
| Agg | Field Name | Type | Description | Optional |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| max_bucket | customMetric | object | Specifies a custom metric configuration to calculate the maximum bucket value. It allows defining the metric to be applied on the buckets. It's a normal metric bucket. | True |
| max_bucket | customBucket | object | Defines a custom bucket aggregation configuration that provides the data for calculating the maximum bucket value. | True |
| avg_bucket | customMetric | object | Defines a custom metric configuration used to calculate the average bucket value. It specifies the metric to be applied over the buckets. It's a normal metric bucket. | True |
| avg_bucket | customBucket | object | Defines a custom bucket aggregation configuration that provides the data for calculating the average value. | True |
| min_bucket | customMetric | object | Specifies a custom metric configuration used to calculate the minimum bucket value. It defines the metric logic to apply. | True |
| min_bucket | customBucket | object | Specifies a custom bucket aggregation configuration that provides the input data for calculating the minimum bucket value. | True |
| sum_bucket | customMetric | object | Specifies a custom metric configuration used to calculate the sum of bucket values. This defines the metric logic to be applied. | True |
| sum_bucket | customBucket | object | Specifies a custom bucket aggregation configuration that provides the input data for calculating the sum of bucket values. | True |



## bucket aggregation
| Agg | Field Name | Type | Description | Optional |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| histogram | field | string | Specifies the numeric field to aggregate on. | False |
| histogram | interval | string | Defines the interval size for histogram buckets. Auto-adjusted if 'auto' is specified. | True |
| histogram | min_doc_count | boolean | Determines whether empty buckets are included. If true, buckets with zero documents are included. | True |
| histogram | has_extended_bounds | boolean | Indicates whether the aggregation uses extended bounds to ensure buckets include specific minimum and maximum values. | True |
| histogram | extended_bounds | object | Specifies the minimum and maximum bounds for the histogram, ensuring buckets extend beyond the actual data range if necessary. | True |
| significant_terms | field | string | Specifies the field from which significant terms are extracted for aggregation. | False |
| significant_terms | size | number | Defines the maximum number of significant terms to retrieve. For instance, setting 'size' to 10 returns the top 10 significant terms. | True |
| range | field | string | Specifies the numeric field to aggregate on. Required for the range aggregation. | False |
| range | ranges | array of objects | Defines the ranges for the aggregation. Each range object includes 'from' and 'to' properties specifying the lower and upper bounds of the range. | True |
| date_histogram | field | string | Specifies the date field to aggregate on. Defaults to the time field defined in the index pattern. | True |
| date_histogram | interval | string | Defines the interval for the histogram, we must select from: 'auto', 's' (means second), 'm' (means minute), 'h' (means hour), 'd' (means day), 'w' (means week), 'M' (means Month), 'q' (means quarter), or 'y' (means year). | True |
| date_histogram | drop_partials | boolean | If true, drops partial buckets at the edges of the time range. | True |
| ip_range | field | string | Specifies the field containing IP addresses for the aggregation. This field must be of type IP. | False |
| ip_range | ipRangeType | string | Specifies the type of IP range aggregation. Options include 'fromTo' for specifying IP ranges with 'from' and 'to' fields, or 'mask' for CIDR mask ranges. | True |
| ip_range | ranges | object | Defines the ranges for the aggregation. Can include 'fromTo' ranges with 'from' and 'to' fields, or CIDR 'mask' ranges. | True |
| terms | field | string | Specifies the field from which unique terms are extracted for aggregation. | False |
| terms | orderBy | string | Determines the metric by which the terms are ordered. Common values include '_count' for document count and '_key' for term value. | True |
| terms | orderAgg | AggConfigSerialized | Specifies a custom aggregation to control the ordering of terms. | True |
| terms | order | string | Specifies the sort direction for the terms, either 'asc' for ascending or 'desc' for descending. | True |
| terms | size | number | Defines the maximum number of unique terms to retrieve. For instance, setting 'size' to 5 returns the top 5 terms. | True |
| terms | otherBucket | boolean | When set to true, groups all terms that don't fall into the top 'size' terms into a single bucket labeled 'Other'. | True |
| terms | otherBucketLabel | string | Provides a custom label for the 'Other' bucket when 'otherBucket' is enabled. | True |
| terms | missingBucket | boolean | If true, includes a bucket for documents where the specified field is missing. | True |
| terms | missingBucketLabel | string | Provides a custom label for the 'Missing' bucket when 'missingBucket' is enabled. | True |
| date_range | field | string | Specifies the date field to aggregate on. Defaults to the time field defined in the index pattern. | True |
| date_range | ranges | array of objects | Defines the date ranges for the aggregation. Each range object contains 'from' and 'to' properties specifying the start and end of the range. | True |

title: [BUG] Zooming in or out the map visualization in a dashboard causes the dot to blow up in size significantly

labels.name: bug

body:
I have a visual bug in a Coordinate map that is in a dashboard. The map looks like this normally:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/bf1b1513-c8be-46a0-8fa5-b4ec25d15d35)

Zooming in or out immediately when viewing the dashboard in which the visualization is hosted (but not when viewing the visualization on its own) causes the dot to blow up in size significantly:

Zooming in:
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5ba65cd7-5b96-4f96-a0c8-cb4c986ee3d7)

Alternatively, zooming out also results in the dots growing significantly):

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b7fe0cd4-a89d-4830-856a-b59619cf5dfa)

Both I and two other users have all encountered this independently (on Google Chrome)

The map type is Shaded circle markers, Geohash aggregation.

The dots should behave in the dashboard as they do when viewing the visualization alone and not blow up in size whenever the zoom is changed.

This is on OpenSearch Dashboards v1.3.2

body:
**Describe the bug**

title: fix: support imports without extensions in cypress webpack build
body:
### Description
When migrating to cypress v12, we saw a small number of regressions due compilation failures in cypress. This change is to resolve this class of issue. Once resolved in this branch I'll create a PR to merge the cypress 12 upgrade in main.

**Details**
By default, cypress' internal webpack preprocessor doesn't allow imports without file extensions. This makes our life a bit hard since if any file in our testing dependency graph has an import without the .js extension our cypress build will fail.

This configuration relaxes this a bit by allowing imports without file extension
     ex. import module from './module'

## Changelog
- fix: support imports without extensions in cypress webpack build

title: [Discover] fix PPL to not throw error if aggregation query fails
body:
### Description

The previous PR https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch-Dashboards/pull/8743 added `handleFacetError` if date_histogram aggregation failed, because otherwise the code will process the response as data, and calling `rawAggs.data.datarows` caused NPE. 

The problem is that some PPL queries will not have a date_histogram, for example `source = table | stats count()`, and failure is expected. So it should not throw error there. This PR changes `handleFacetError` to `continue`, and renames `handleFacetError` to `throwFacetError`.

### Issues Resolved

- skip

If currently viewing a visualization or dashboard with filters applied, navigating to the Discover page will cause those filters to be there on the Discover page.

Cover remaining untested functions within PPL and SQL, ensuring that the suggestions are accurate. Tests should be written for "preferred rules", or in general areas where custom logic was written instead of relying on the grammar for these languages.

So far, this includes suggesting table names, suggesting aggregate functions for PPL and SQL.

What to test

Permutations to consider (only if they apply)

Data type:

  1. Index Patterns

  2. Indexes

  3. S3 Connections (future)

  4. Cloudwatch

  5. Security Lake

Language:

  1. DQL

  2. PPL

  3. SQL

| Scenario | Steps | Expected result | Notes | |----------|-------|-----------------|-------| | Example (See below) | | | | | PPL/SQL table name |
  • For PPL, test with `source =`.
  • For SQL, test with `SELECT * FROM`.
| table name appears | | | PPL/SQL aggregate functions |
  • Test PPL by writing in a command with `stats`, and the suggestions should appear as expected. All the aggregate functions include a 'snippet' which should allow for tabbing into the inside of the parentheses.
  • Test SQL by putting in a `WHERE` clause, and verify that aggregate functions appear.
| aggregate functions appear | |

Pre-requisites

What do we need to make sure the test can be written

labels.description: Issues that are specific to the Discover 2.0 testing initiative

body:
Objective

Test that compounding queries through logical operators (AND / OR ) don't interfere with other suggestions. This is mostly to test value suggestion but also other future developments that require another parse of the query or a symbol table.

What to test

Permutations to consider (only if they apply)

Data type:

  1. Index Patterns

  2. Indexes

  3. S3 Connections (future)

  4. Cloudwatch

  5. Security Lake

Language:

  1. DQL

  2. PPL

  3. SQL

| Scenario | Steps | Expected result | Notes | |----------|-------|-----------------|-------| | Example (See below) | | | | | DQL Value Suggestion |
  • Write a query in the format `: ` and `:`, where `field1` and `field2` are different.
  • Verify that the next value suggestions are accurate to `field2`.
  • Append another partially formed value to `field2`, and check that the suggestions are as expected.
|
  • The values that appear without any partially formed value should be correct.
  • The values that appear with it partially formed should be correct.
| | | PPL/SQL Value Suggestion |
  • Write a query in the format `SELECT * FROM WHERE = AND =`, where `field1` and `field2` are different.
  • Verify that the next value suggestions are accurate to `field2`.
|
  • The values that appear without any partially formed value should be correct.
| |

title: [Discover Autocomplete] TESTID-80: Autocomplete Languages - DQL, SQL, PPL - Verify values

labels.name: discover_2.0-test
labels.description: Issues that are specific to the Discover 2.0 testing initiative

body:
Objective

Values are a separate process from keywords or fields. They require some sort of querying aggregation done, with a field name also being required. This tests failure points for value suggestion

What to test

Data type:

  1. Index Patterns

  2. Indexes

  3. S3 Connections (future)

  4. Cloudwatch

  5. Security Lake

Language:

  1. DQL

  2. PPL

  3. SQL

| Scenario | Steps | Expected result | Notes | |----------|-------|-----------------|-------| | Example (See below) | | | | | DQL |
  • Put in a field name, the OSD type should be `keyword`.
  • Drop a colon after the field name if it isn't already there.
  • Look for suggestions and verify that they are expected values.
  • Test a field that isn't of type `keyword`, to ensure there aren't any suggested values.
  • Test a partially formed value.
|
  • The values should be the top 10 values for the field, using whatever partially formed value there is.
| | | PPL |
  • Form a query in the format `source = | where =` . Ensure that the field is in the index and the field is of OSD type `keyword`.
  • Look for suggestions and verify that they are the expected values.
  • Replace the query in step 1 with `source = | where in (,` and verify the values are as expected.
  • Test a field that isn't of type `keyword`, to ensure there aren't any suggested values.
|
  • The values should be the top X values of that field, where X is set in the advanced settings under `query:enhancements:suggestValuesLimit`.
| | | SQL |
  • Form a query in the format `SELECT * FROM WHERE =` . Ensure that the field is in the index and the field is of OSD type `keyword`.
  • Look for suggestions and verify that they are the expected values.
  • Replace the query in step 1 with `SELECT * FROM
    • WHERE IN (,` and verify the values are as expected.
  • Test a field that isn't of type `keyword`, to ensure there aren't any suggested values.
    • |
    • The values should be the top X values of that field, where X is set in the advanced settings under `query:enhancements:suggestValuesLimit`.
    | |

    Pre-requisites

    What do we need to make sure the test can be written

    Steps to setting up the scenario

    1. Have at least 1 existing workspace with index patterns

    2. Turn query enhancements on

    3. Select the index pattern

    4. Select the language for the test

    5. Ensure query:enhancements:suggestValues is on and query:enhancements:suggestValuesLimit is set properly

    Known Issues

    List of known issues to reference that could impact the results of this test case

title: [Discover Autocomplete] TESTID-80: Autocomplete Languages - DQL, SQL, PPL - Verify field names appear in valid contexts

labels.name: discover_2.0-test
labels.description: Issues that are specific to the Discover 2.0 testing initiative

body:
Objective

Each language has a place or places where field names are expected to appear. This differs from how keywords are generated based on the language, and so is a potential point of failure. This test ensures that the field names are being delivered properly as well as appear in the right places.

What to test

Data type:

  1. Index Patterns

  2. Indexes

  3. S3 Connections (future)

  4. Cloudwatch

  5. Security Lake

Language:

  1. DQL

  2. PPL

  3. SQL

| Scenario | Steps | Expected result | Notes | |----------|-------|-----------------|-------| | Example (See below) | | | | | DQL |
  • Click into the query editor
  • The very first suggestions should contain field names
|
  • The suggestions should be the same as the fields that appear in the sidebar, i.e. the fields for the selected dataset
|
  • The datasets contain duplicate fields which get filtered out, that appear with `.keyword` appended. Tests should include these types of datasets.
| | PPL |
  • Start forming the query `source = |` to get all basic PPL commands.
  • Write in `where`.
  • Verify that the next suggestions include all the fields in the current dataset.
  • Repeat 2-3 for `eval`, `grok`, `parse`, `patterns`.
|
  • The suggestions should be the same as the fields that appear in the sidebar, i.e. the fields for the selected dataset
|
  • The datasets contain duplicate fields which get filtered out, that appear with `.keyword` appended. Tests should include these types of datasets.
| | SQL |
  • Write `SELECT` and check that field names appear in the suggestion window.
  • Write a new query `SELECT * FROM ` to get all basic SQL commands.
  • Write in `WHERE`.
  • Verify that the next suggestions include all the fields in the current dataset.
  • Repeat 3-4 for `HAVING`, `ORDER BY`, and other cases where an expression might appear.
    • |
    • The suggestions should be the same as the fields that appear in the sidebar, i.e. the fields for the selected dataset.
    |
    • The datasets contain duplicate fields which get filtered out, that appear with `.keyword` appended. Tests should include these types of datasets.
    |

    Pre-requisites

    Steps to setting up the scenario

    1. Have at least 1 existing workspace with index patterns

    2. Turn query enhancements on

    3. Select the index pattern

    4. Select the language for the test

    Known Issues

    List of known issues to reference that could impact the results of this test case

title: [Discover Autocomplete] TESTID-80: Autocomplete Languages - DQL, SQL, PPL - Verify grammar keywords are being generated

labels.name: discover_2.0-test
labels.description: Issues that are specific to the Discover 2.0 testing initiative

body:
Objective

For each language, verify that the grammar is being used by testing queries for certain keywords and patterns. The grammars are assumed to be correct for SQL & PPL, so just verifying that they're being used should be enough.

What to test

Data type:

  1. Index Patterns

  2. Indexes

  3. S3 Connections (future)

  4. Cloudwatch

  5. Security Lake

Language:

  1. PPL

  2. SQL

| Scenario | Steps | Expected result | Notes | |---------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------| | Example (See below) | | | | | PPL |
  • Try testing a query with `source = index | head 10` and verify that the suggestions for the keywords are being generated properly along each step of the way.
  • Type a word in the query.
  • Check the suggestion window that the suggestions are as expected.
  • Repeat 2-3 until the query is formed.
|
  • The first word should show source, describe, etc., then the equal operator, pipe, basic PPL functions, such as head.
|
  • Ignore checking the index name, to let another test fail for it.
| | SQL |
  • Try testing `SELECT * FROM table LIMIT 10` and verify suggestions for each step of the way.
  • Type a word in the query.
  • Check the suggestion window that the suggestions are as expected.
  • Repeat 2-3 until the query is formed.
|
  • Like the expected result for PPL, each step of the way should include the right keywords for SQL.
|
  • Also like PPL, ignore table name and field names.
|

Pre-requisites

Steps to setting up the scenario

  1. Have at least 1 existing workspace with index patterns

  2. Turn query enhancements on

  3. Select the index pattern

  4. Select the language for the test

Known Issues

title: [Caching (cover it in user workflows)] TESTID-77: Test scenario

labels.name: discover_2.0-test
labels.description: Issues that are specific to the Discover 2.0 testing initiative

body:
Objective

Caching in Discover

What to test

Data type:

  1. Index Patterns

  2. Indexes

  3. S3 Connections

  4. Cloudwatch

  5. Security Lake

Language:

  1. DQL

  2. Lucene

  3. PPL

  4. SQL

| Scenario | Steps | Expected result | Notes | |------------------------------|--------|-----------------|-------| | Caching data structures |
  • Start with an empty cache.
  • Open the dataset selector and click View all available data.
  • Select the indexes dataset type.
  • Select a cluster.
  • Exit the advanced dataset selector.
  • Repeat steps 1-3.
|
  • On the second try, there should be no network calls.
  • The list of indexes should match the ones that were in the first run when they were returned by the first call.
|   | | Last cache time |
  • Start with an empty cache.
  • Open the dataset selector and click View all available data.
  • Select the indexes dataset type.
  • Select a cluster.
|
  • Once the request to fetch indexes for a cluster has been initiated, the last cache time should be updated to when that request was fired/completed.
|   | | Clear cache |
  • Start with a populated cache (could follow any of the procedures in the above scenarios).
  • Open the dataset selector and click View all available data.
  • Click the clear cache button.
  • Revisit a column that was previously in the cache.
|
  • The last cache time should no longer be displayed and there should be a request to fetch what was previously in the cache.
|   | | Session ID |
  • Start with an empty cache.
  • Open the dataset selector and click View all available data.
  • Select the S3 dataset type.
  • Select a data source and cluster.
  • Once the databases have been loaded, load the tables.
  • Select a table and complete the configurator flow to Select Data.
|
  • The first request for databases should not have a session ID attached to it.
  • The subsequent requests (to get the list of tables and to run the actual query) should have the session ID that was returned by the databases call.
|   | | Recent dataset |
  • Set Maximum datasets in recents list to a different number other than the default.
|
  • Go back to discover and check the # of recent datasets.
  • Should not be more than the number we set.
|   | | Index/Index pattern reloads |
  • Choose an index pattern as dataset.
  • Go to the index pattern page and create a new index pattern.
  • Navigate to discover and open the dataset selector.
|
  • Since index and index pattern are not cached, so we always refetch, we should be able to see the new index pattern loads.
|   | | Clear cache (Log out) |
  • Open the dataset selector, and do not press reset cache.
  • Log out of the application.
  • Open dataset selector again.
|
  • Should see a loading spinner since cache should be cleared on log out.
|   | | Recent dataset in terms of workspace |
  • Go to workspace A, and select a dataset.
  • Go to workspace B.
|
  • Workspace B should not show workspace A's recent dataset.
|   |


Pre-requisites

What do we need to make sure the test can be written

Steps to setting up the scenario

  1. Have at least 1 existing workspace with indexes and S3 connections

  • Click "Filter for value" (+ button).
  • Verify the filter appears in the filter bar.
  • Check the updated results.
  • Repeat with "Filter out value" (- button).

  • Filter pills should be removable.

labels.name: discover_2.0-test

body:
Objective
---------

Execute multiple queries and verify they appear in recent queries

What to test
------------

  

1\.  PPL recent query
    
      1.  Steps:
          
              1.  Choose a index pattern
                  
              2.  Send a PPL query: source = opensearch\_dashboards\_sample\_data\_ecommerce
                  
              3.  Choose a index
                  
              4.  Send a PPL query: source = opensearch\_dashboards\_sample\_data\_flights
                  
              5.  Send an invalid PPL query: source =
          
              6.  Check recent query
          
      2.  expected result:
          
            1.  Should see three recent PPL queries in a stack order:
                
            2.  1st: `source =`
                
            3.  2nd: `source = opensearch_dashboards_sample_data_flights`
                
            4.  3rd: `source = opensearch_dashboards_sample_data_ecommerce`
    

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e4b01d8f-8b61-4e81-baa4-aeffcda57646)

  

2\. SQL recent query

        1.  Steps:
            
              1.  Choose a index pattern
                  
              2.  Send a SQL query: `SELECT * FROM opensearch_dashboards_sample_data_flights LIMIT 10`
                  
              3.  Choose a index
                  
              4.  Send a SQL query: `SELECT * FROM opensearch_dashboards_sample_data_ecommerce LIMIT 10`\`
                  
              5.  Send an invalid SQL query: `SELECT * FROM`
                  
              6.  Check recent query
    
        2.  expected result:
            
            1.  Should see three recent SQL queries in a stack order:
                
            2.  1st: `SELECT * FROM`
                
            3.  2nd: `SELECT * FROM opensearch_dashboards_sample_data_ecommerce LIMIT 10`

title: Revert "[augmenter] do not support datasources with no version (#8915)"

labels.name: Skip-Changelog
labels.description: PRs that are too trivial to warrant a changelog or release notes entry

body:
This reverts commit 539675e688061e689b362801bcb05a3ef78431b2.

There is a known issue with the bundled JS after this change, when trying to render eligible visualizations. The AD/Alerting options fail to render, due to issues fetching the underlying `getIndexPatterns` fn within `isEligibleForVisLayers`. This is due to how the JS modules are bundled along with a mismatch on when these functions are defined in `setup()`/`start()` phases of the plugins.

Future work to add this functionality in a safe manner is tracked in #8924.

**Describe the bug**

I have a Controls visualization. I added the index-pattern and the field. At the moment of using the Controls visualization I receive a message "Filtering occurs on the <field>, which doesn't exist on any documents in the <index-pattern>. Choose a different field or index documents that contain values for this field". 
When looking in the Discover section, I can see the field, and can even filter by them. Also, directly in the dashboard, in the filters section I can add the field and I get the results.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Go to Create New Visualization
2. Select Controls visualization
3. Add a Control label name
4. Scroll down to Index Pattern section
5. Select the index pattern (already exists)
6. Scroll down to Field section
7. Select the field (it's in the list option)
8. Scroll down to the bottom and click on the Update Button
9. Go to the visualization in the left side
10. Click in the new control option
11. See error  message about "Filtering occurs on the..."

**Expected behavior**
The behavior is
1. Click in the control option
2. Show a list of the values for the field

title: [Feature Request] Global font size settings to adjust font size of axis labels

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

body: ### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe I am experiencing difficulty adjusting the font size of the x and y-axis labels in OpenSearch Dashboards visualizations. The default font size is too small for presentations or displays that require larger text for better readability. Currently, there is no straightforward way to universally change the font size of axis labels through the user interface or settings. When inspecting the elements of a visualization, I see that the axis label text elements have a font-size set to 8pt. Manually changing this value in the browser's developer tools to 18pt provides the desired readability but is not a sustainable solution. ` 0` ### Describe the solution you'd like I would like OpenSearch Dashboards to provide an option to adjust the font size of axis labels in visualizations. This feature could be implemented in several ways: Global Font Size Setting: A global configuration option in OpenSearch Dashboards settings that allows users to set the default font size for axis labels across all visualizations. Visualization-Level Font Size Control: An option within the visualization editor under a "Style" or "Appearance" tab where users can adjust the font size for axis labels on a per-visualization basis. Accessibility Enhancements: Including font size adjustments as part of accessibility features to improve readability for all users. ### Related component Other ### Describe alternatives you've considered I have explored several alternative solutions, but they have significant limitations: Custom CSS Injection via Browser Extensions: - Attempted Solution: Using browser extensions like Stylish Issue: This method did not work on my OpenSearch Dashboards instance (https://localhost:9200/_dashboards/...). The styles did not apply, possibly due to content security policies or the way OpenSearch Dashboards handles inline styles and component rendering. ### Additional context Impact on Users: - Improved readability for presentations, reports, and dashboards viewed on large screens or projectors. - Enhanced accessibility for users with visual impairments.

title: [BUG] [Discover] index pattern fetch error in discover dataset modal

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

body:
**Describe the bug**

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/09b4964a-f989-49bb-85d3-fac5c3b6091c)
When clicking left index pattern item in discover dataset modal, it will use `find` to get all index patterns and use `bulk_get` to get all reference data sources in returned index patterns. If one of these data sources is dissociated with current workspace, non dashboard admin user wouldn't have access to this object and bulk_get request would fail because of ACL which would cause the modal always be in loading state.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/87495f6f-c7b9-4bc2-9311-349804899a28)
Index pattern list page uses `find` to find all available data sources and uses response to match index pattern reference for data source connection state, so it will work normally in this case.

For availability, discover dataset modal should use `find` to get data sources instead of  `bulk_get` to keep consistent with index pattern page.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Use dashboard admin to create a workspace, associate data source and create index patterns.
2. Dissociate the data source.
3. Non dashboard admin user would see this error when in discover data set modal.

**Expected behavior**
Discover data set modal should display currently available index patterns for all kinds users.

title: [Workspace] Isolate objects based on workspace when calling get/bulkGet
body:
### Description

Isolate objects based on workspace when calling get/bulkGet

1. Global operation (option/request workspace id is null): Return object;
2. `option.worksapces.length` > 1: Throw error; 
3. Workspace operation: 
	1. Object is data source:
		1. User is data source admin: Return object;
		2. Global data source: Do not return the object;
		3. Validate data source whether belongs to the workspace
	2. Other object:
		1. Global object: Return object;
		2. Validate object whether belongs to the workspace

### Issues Resolved

title: DarkMode settings apply globally per tenant and not per user

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

body:
In the lastest version of OpenSearch Dashboards (2.18.0), darkmode settings is user-specific but only applies globally within the "global" tenant. This means that if a user in tenant X activates dark mode, all other users within that same tenant are affected, and vice versa.
[[#2159]](https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch-Dashboards/issues/2159)

Similarly, users must manually switch to dark mode for each tenant they have access to. However, logically, when a user decides to enable dark mode, it should apply across all the tenants they access.

This creates inconsistencies in the user experience when navigating between different tenants.

title: [BUG] Settings described on the `opensearch_dashboards.yaml` file don't exist in fact

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

body:
**Describe the bug**
Some of the settings described on the `opensearch_dashboards.yaml` file don't exist in fact.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Open the cloned project, go to `config/opensearch_dashboards.yml`.
2. Enable the settings below.
3. See error.

* On this line, it says the configuration would work: https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch-Dashboards/blob/2.18.0/config/opensearch_dashboards.yml#L367
`FATAL  ValidationError: [config validation of [data].enhancements.enabled]: definition for this key is missing`
```yaml
data:
  enhancements:
    enabled: true
  savedQueriesNewUI:
    enabled: true
```

* On this line, it says the configuration could be boolean if I don't want the survey: https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch-Dashboards/blob/2.18.0/config/opensearch_dashboards.yml#L334
`[config validation of [opensearchDashboards].survey.url]: expected value of type [string] but got [boolean]`
```yaml
opensearchDashboards:
  survey:
    url: false
```

**Expected behavior**
To happen what it says on the documentation.

**OpenSearch Version**
2.18.0

**Dashboards Version**
2.18.0

Any.

title: [BUG] Importing from src/plugin/data/common cause commonJS module to get bundled with plugin

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

body:
When plugin code imports from `src/plugin/data/common`, it ends up importing and bundling [kuery.js](https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch-Dashboards/blob/main/src/plugins/data/common/opensearch_query/kuery/ast/_generated_/kuery.js) which is a CommonJS module and end up breaking the app at run time with error `Cannot assign to readonly property exports of #object`

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/73448d38-76fb-47a2-b3a0-8510d6971c37)

**Expected behavior**
The browser compatible ES module should be made available so that code gets bundles correctly

**OpenSearch Version**
2.17

**Dashboards Version**
2.17

**Plugins**
Security Analytics Dashboards
Alerting Dashboards

title: Fix SurroundingDocsView with URI encoded chars in document id

labels.name: discover
labels.description: for discover reinvent

labels.name: Skip-Changelog
labels.description: PRs that are too trivial to warrant a changelog or release notes entry

body:
When viewing surrounding documents of a document which id contains chars
such as `@` or `+`, these chars are encoded, preventing OpenSearch from
finding the requested document.

Decode the id to transform back the URI encoded chars to the actual
chars in the document id to find it and unbreak the feature.

Fixes #5711

Signed-off-by: Romain Tartière <romain@blogreen.org>

## Changelog

- skip

title: [Workspace][Bug] Fix inspect page url error
body: ### Description 1. When workspace and new home page are disable, clicking the inspect button will show 404 error. 2. When workspace and new home page are enabled, clicking the inspect button in the relationship page will go to the global inspect page. ### Issues Resolved After solving the issue 1, clicking inspect button will go to the inspect page After solving the issue 2, clicking inspect button in the relationship will go to the workspace inspect page. ## Screenshot ## Testing the changes ## Changelog - fix: [Workspace][Bug] Fix inspect page url error. ### Check List - [ ] All tests pass - [ ] `yarn test:jest` - [ ] `yarn test:jest_integration` - [ ] New functionality includes testing. - [ ] New functionality has been documented. - [ ] Update [CHANGELOG.md](./../CHANGELOG.md) - [ ] Commits are signed per the DCO using --signoff
